Two British scientists have predicted that the warmer global temperatures caused by the ''greenhouse effect'' will cause the world's oceans to rise in the next 40 years by at least four to eight centimeters (1 1/2 to 3 1/4 inches). This would result purely from the expansion of the water caused by the higher temperature. The calculation, they said, does not take into account the melting of polar and glacial ice that may also occur with a warming atmosphere, which would further raise the sea level.

Dr. Tom Wigley and Dr. S. C. B. Raper of the University of East Anglia presented in Nature their estimate of the impact of ocean expansion caused by the rising level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere resulting from the burning of fossil fuels and other human activities.

Carbon dioxide and certain other gases trap solar heat in the atmosphere. The heated atmosphere will transfer heat to the oceans by diffusion and upwelling currents, they asserted, and this would expand the water. A rise of 3 1/4 inches would not cause serious coastal flooding, but coupled with the effects of melted glaciers, flooding might become serious.
